Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
sublime-keybindings|ms-|2.9.1
twig|wha|1.0.2
vscode-twig-pack|baj|1.0.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I have twig configured with emmet by added `"twig": "html"` to `emmet.syntaxProfiles` and `emmet.includeLanguages` so emmet as a whole works okay. 
2. From an HTML twig template when I execute something like `.row>.col-md` emmet will respond just fine. If however I do `.row>.col-md-5` emmet doesn't respond at all.

Issues still happen when vscode-twig-pack is deactivated which leads me to think it's associated with the built in extension.

data.title: Emmet snippets not working for XSL language mode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (0b6da14128b4e61e331193f18786e8db2792a643, 2017-08-11T19:14:29.146Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create new file and set  language mode to `xsl`
2. Input `xsl` and call `Emmet: expand abbreviation`

The result is:
```
<!!!></!!!>
<xsl:stylesheet version="1.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform"> |</xsl:stylesheet>
```

Desired output is:
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xsl:stylesheet version="1.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform"> |</xsl:stylesheet>
```

Abbreviation being expanded:
```
"xsl": "!!!+xsl:stylesheet[version=1.0 xmlns:xsl=http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform]>{\n|}"
```
from default snippets.json

Snippet for `!!!` is:
```
"!!!": "<?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"UTF-8\"?>"
```
also from default snippets.json

I've also tried to expand `!!!` directly and an turns to `<!!!></!!!>` as well.

Expanding snippet `!!!` for HTML grammar works as expected.

I haven't set `"emmet.extensionsPath"`

data.title: Replicate functionality of "build system" in Sublime Text

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I am looking for something like what Sublime Text does. In Sublime Text, you can define a "build system" which may be associated with a file extension. The build system is a user-defined shell command. You can then build a file with your build system without having to have a project or workspace set up. However when I try to do the same thing in vscode using "build tasks", I get an error saying "Tasks are only available on a workspace folder". I don't want to have to create/open a workspace folder if I want to build a simple script.

Could you possibly imitate the functionality of Sublime Text?

- VSCode Version: 1.15
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new file (i.e. index.php)
2. Go to `Tasks > Run Build Tasks` or `Tasks > Configure Tasks`
3. A error notification pops up saying "Tasks are only available on a workspace folder"

Expected Outcome:
Instead of the error notification, I should be able to run and configure tasks without having a project. This is how Sublime Text works.

My snippet in "javascript.json" file:

```
"(function() {...})()": {
  "prefix": "()()",
  "body": [
    "(function() {",
    "\t",
    "})()"
  ],
  "description": "(function() {...})()"
}
```

So, the prefix is just made of symbols - ()()
It will show snippet for "f()()", and it will show snippet for "()()f", but not just ()()

data.title: Enhancement: Ability to transliterate and auto-complete

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is an enhancement request.

I like Visual Studio Code. It is truly cross platform and is easily available everywhere. I would request to add support for transliteration to visual studio code. Right now, if I have to type a text in a non-roman language, say Tamil, (may be for a web page or a .po file, etc.) I need to go to a browser, type the content that I want, copy it and then come back to Code and paste here. This workflow could be optimised if there is native support for transliteration within Code.

We can already change the keyboard language setting from the browser and type with a different keyboard. But what I would like to have is a more intelligent transliteration system that can potentially talk to a web API (like google https://www.google.com/inputtools/try/ ) or my own plugin. This will save some typing by intelligent auto-completion without expecting the user to type all the text. 

I would even try to contribute this, if this can be achieved as an extension. In case, something is not clear, please ask and I can elaborate. Thanks.

data.title: Improve extension recommendations (August milestone)
data.body:
Currently the extension recommendations come from 2 sources
- a curated list of extensions mapped to filetypes maintained by the VS Code team. 
- the extension list inside the `.vscode/extensions.json` file in a workspace which is maintained by the workspace owners

A framework that can help explain to the user why and how these recommendations are made is missing

This issue tracks work in improving the extension recommendation system and will span over several iterations.

Things to achieve
- Users should **understand why** a recommendation is being made. A recommendation can be
    - based on current file type
    - based on current workspace
    - history of types of files opened
- [x] **Recommendations should be relevant**. For example: User opens a php file long time ago, gets recommendation for a php extension, never again opens a php file. The recommendation continues to show up today. Files/workspaces used more often should influence recommendations than files/workspaces rarely used
- **Recommendations list should be short and well sorted as per relevance**. For example: the recommendation for current file type and workspace can show up before the ones based on historical usage (moved to September milestone)

We need telemetry in place to
- [x] determine whether recommendations are successful
- [x] assess the success of different ways of presenting recommendations
- associate extensions with features like format/lint/completion/outline etc This can in the future help in recommending by category (moved to September milestone)

data.title: Ability to toggle showing CodeLens [feature request]
data.body:
First, big shout out for guy behind Toggle CodeLens extensions, which toggles editor.codeLens value in the settings on keyboard shortcut.

CodeLens is very useful, the problem with it is it can easily take an unhealthy amount of space in some situations relatively to the amount of code. I keep it on most of the time, and want to the hide it from time to time.

What is currently missing with "toggle editor.codeLens" method is that: 1) it does full rebuild of the index, which can take up some time and is annoying 2) I think enabling it while on page doesn't make CodeLens pop in back as you would expect, looks like it checks for value only on page load.

I can imagine having "codeLensHidden" bool which would just toggle code lens on UI level, but I assume keeping cache between codeLens disable/enable to be possible

data.title: On linux the defalut `$SHELL` is` /bin/zsh` But Task runner run taks in `/bin/bash`
data.body:
In my Linux machine the default shell is zsh but when i run tasks it run them in /bin/bash. It doesn't make any problem when you are not printing to the console like compiling a C program a bash session starts and ends in the integrated terminal but when you want to read the output it results in a flashing behavior. Maybe there is a setting that says use the default shell for running tasks but unfortunately i can't find it. 

I'm using Ubuntu zesty (17.04) with VS Code 1.16.0-insider

data.title: JSDoc callbacks unsupported in Node.js
data.body:
VSCode with Node.js does not allow me to use callbacks when using JSDoc comments.

I have to do things like:

```Node.js
/**

*/
```

but then it adds these weird 'arg0, arg1, arg2...' to it when i would rather it say something like

`response: string`

data.title: Add docker-compose.yaml highlight as docker file
data.body:
In https://docs.docker.com/compose/compose-file/#service-configuration-reference you can find next:
>Tip: You can use either a .yml or .yaml extension for this file. They both work.

Because many of developers use `.yaml` extension instead `.yml`, it's good idea add highlight for both variant.

data.title: Automatically restart ts server after disableAutomaticTypeAcquisition config changed
data.body:
Now Code will automatically restart TypeScript server when some config about TypeScript has been changed, but why not for `typescript.disableAutomaticTypeAcquisition`?

This pull request adds the detection for `typescript.disableAutomaticTypeAcquisition` config and restart TypeScript server when it is changed.

data.title: Alternative line comment behaviour
data.body:
It would be great for efficiency if a setting could be introduced to change the behaviour of the editor when `editor.action.commentLine` is performed.

Currently the cursor stays at the current line und performing `editor.action.commentLine` repeatedly switches between comment and uncomment for that line.

I very much like the behaviour of the editor in Jetbrains IntelliJ based products (PyCharm, WebStorm, IDEA, RubyMine, etc.). When you comment a single line the cursor moves down to the line below. Thus subsequently performing this action one can quickly comment multiple lines without having to mark the lines first. However having marked some lines and then performing this action does not move the cursor or the marking. As it should be IMHO.
